title: Acoustic Shock

demographics.country_region: UK/Commonwealth (implied by 'General Practitioner' and 'District General Hospital')

chief_complaint: I experienced sudden, severe pain and a sensation that my head was about to explode after a patient screamed into my headset. Since then, I have been extremely sensitive to sound and feel like my hearing is muffled.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset following an acoustic incident at work (scream through intercom headset).
problem_summary.course: Initial pain and muffled sensation; hearing thresholds remained normal, but sound sensitivity and anxiety (specifically regarding telephones) persisted and worsened over the following month.
problem_summary.laterality: Right ear (exposed ear), though symptoms affect general well-being.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Physical ear pain, aural fullness, hyperacusis, phonophobia (fear of telephones), sleep disturbance (delayed onset/early waking), anxiety/panic attacks.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe difficulty performing workplace duties due to fear of telephones; feels disbelieved by family and employer.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking validation and proof of her condition after being told initial exams were normal.

history.present_illness: Patient presented 2 days after an incident where a person screamed into her intercom headset (right ear). Reported sudden pain, 'head exploding' sensation, muffled hearing, and blockage. No sustained tinnitus or vertigo.
history.noise_exposure_history: Acute acoustic trauma via intercom headset.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing thresholds across the frequency range 250 Hz to 8 kHz.

numeric_results.Thresholds: 0-10 dB HL across all frequencies (visual estimate from Fig 14.1)

history.present_illness: Referral 1 month post-exposure. Sleep issues had largely resolved, but anxiety regarding telephones persisted. Reported sudden noise from children causes pain; traffic noise is unpleasant. Able to tolerate jazz exercise class.
history.medical_psych_history: History of hypothyroidism (controlled). Sleep disturbance immediately post-injury. Anxiety/panic attacks related to telephone use.
history.prior_management: Reassurance from A&E (V1) that symptoms would settle.
history.patient_goals: Desperate for 'proof' of condition as she feels disbelieved by employer and family.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs)
tests.key_findings: Abnormal LDLs confirmed, worse on the affected (right) side. Testing started at threshold due to anxiety.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Hearing thresholds remain within normal limits (0-10 dB HL), consistent with V1.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal pure-tone thresholds and normal middle ear function (Type A tympanograms). However, Loudness Discomfort Level (LDL) testing reveals significantly reduced sound tolerance (hyperacusis), which is more severe in the right ear (the ear exposed to the acoustic shock). The findings support a diagnosis of acoustic shock with associated phonophobia.
counseling_points: Validate the patient's experience: Acoustic Shock is a real condition, even if standard hearing tests look 'normal'.
Explain that the pain and sensitivity are due to a temporary change in how the auditory system processes loudness, not necessarily permanent physical damage.
Recommend using environmental sound enrichment (e.g., nature sounds) to help desensitize the auditory system.
Advise against silence or over-protection (earplugs), as this can increase sensitivity.
Discuss relaxation training to manage the anxiety response associated with the sound exposure.
Advise using environmental sound rather than ear-level sound generators initially.
notes_for_actor: You are anxious and defensive because people (family, work) think you are making it up since your first hearing test was normal.
You have a specific phobia of telephones now—the idea of putting a receiver to your ear causes panic.
Describe the pain as a physical sensation in the ear, not just that sounds are 'too loud'.
You are relieved when the audiologist finally finds a test (LDLs) that shows something is actually wrong.
